captions.text:
My wife is pregnant right
now with our first child,

and when people see her
with her big baby bump,

the first question people ask,
almost without fail, is,
"Is it a boy or is it a girl?"

Now, there are some assumptions
behind that question
that we take for granted

because of our familiarity
with our own human biology.

For human babies, we take it for granted
that there's a 50/50 chance
of either answer, boy or girl.
But why is it that way?

Well, the answer depends
on the sex determination system
that has evolved for our species.
You see, for most mammals,

the sex of a baby
is determined genetically
with the XY chromosome system.
Mammals have a pair of sex chromosomes,

one passed down from mom,
and one from dad.
A pair of X's gives us a girl,
and an X and a Y together gives us a boy.

Since females only have X's to pass
on in their egg cells,

and males can give either an X
or a Y in their sperm cells,
the sex is determined by the father

and the chance of producing
a male or a female is 50/50.
This system has worked well for mammals,

but throughout the tree of life,
we can see other systems

that have worked just
as well for other animals.

There are other groups of animals
that also have genetic sex determination,

but their systems can be
pretty different from ours.

Birds and some reptiles have
their sex genetically determined,

but instead of the sex
being determined by dad,
their sex is determined by mom.

In those groups,
a pair of Z sex chromosomes

produces a male, so these males
only have Z's to give.

However, in these animals,
one Z and one W chromosome together,
as a pair, produces a female.

In this system, the chance of a male
or a female is still 50/50,

it just depends on whether
mom puts a Z or a W
into her egg.

Certain groups have taken
genetic sex determination
in completely other directions.

Ants, for example, have
one of the most interesting systems

for determining sex, and because of it,
if you are a male ant,
you do not have a father.

In an ant colony, there
are dramatic divisions of labor.
There are soldiers that defend the colony,

there are workers that collect food,
clean the nest and care for the young,

and there's a queen and a small group
of male reproductives.

Now, the queen will mate and then
store sperm from the males.

And this is where the system
gets really interesting.

If the queen uses the stored
sperm to fertilize an egg,

then that egg will grow up
to become female.

However, if she lays an egg
without fertilizing it,

then that egg will still
grow up to be an ant,
but it will always be a male.

So you see, it's impossible
for male ants to have fathers.

And male ants live their life like this,
with only one copy of every gene,
much like a walking sex cell.

This system is called
a haplodiploid system,
and we see it not only in ants,

but also in other highly social
insects like bees and wasps.
Since our own sex is determined by genes,

and we do know of these other animals
that have their sex determined by genes,
it's easy to assume that for all animals

the sex of their babies still
must be determined by genetics.

However, for some animals, the question
of whether it will be a boy or a girl
has nothing to do with genes at all,

and it can depend on something
like the weather.

These are animals like alligators
and most turtles.

In these animals, the sex
of an embryo in a developing egg
is determined by the temperature.
In these species, the sex of the baby

is not yet determined
when the egg is laid,

and it remains undetermined
until sometime in the middle

of the overall development period,
when a critical time is reached.

And during this time, the sex
is completely determined
by temperature in the nest.
In painted turtles, for example,

warm temperatures
above the critical temperature
will produce females within the eggs,
and cool temperatures will produce a male.

I'm not sure who came up
with this mnemonic,

but you can remember that when
it comes to painted turtles,
they are all hot chicks and cool dudes.

For some tropical fish, the question
of will it be a boy or will it be a girl
isn't settled until even later in life.

You see, clownfish all start
out their lives as males,

However, as they mature,
they become female.

They also spend their lives in small
groups with a strict dominance hierarchy

where only the most dominant
male and female reproduce.

And amazingly, if the dominant
female in the group dies,

the largest and most dominant male
will then quickly become female

and take her place,
and all of the other males
will move up one rank in the hierarchy.
In another very different ocean animal,
the green spoonworm,
the sex of the babies is determined

by a completely different aspect
of the environment.

For this species, it is simply
a matter of where a larva
happens to randomly fall on the sea floor.

If a larva lands on the open sea floor,
then it will become a female.

But if it lands on top of a female,
then it will become a male.

So for some species,
the question of boy or girl
is answered by genetics.

For others, it's answered
by the environment.

And for others still, they don't even
bother with the question at all.
Take whiptail lizards, for example.

For those desert lizards,
the answer is easy.
It's a girl. It's always a girl.

They are a nearly all-female species,
and although they still lay eggs,

these eggs hatch out
female clones of themselves.
So will it be a girl or will it be a boy?
Throughout the entire animal kingdom,

it does really all depend
on the system of sex determination.

For humans, that system
is a genetic XY system.
And for me and my wife, we found out
it's going to be a baby boy.
(Kiss)

title: Sex determination: More complicated than you thought - Aaron Reedy

comments.author: Carlos Vorece

comments.text:
I don't get why people are using this to relate to homosexuality. I'm not 
against it or anything (you can be gay, IDGAF) but I'm tired of people 
using science to prove/disprove homosexuality. If anything, the video is 
against homosexuality. Sure, many animals have different sex determination 
systems, no where in it that says that male ants or whatever species are 
fucking one another or something. If they are, chances are they don't have 
sex assigned to them yet or their sexes can change/determined later in 
life. But male and female homo sapiens clearly have their sex determined at 
birth and their sexes are not naturally changeable at all. Unless if you 
can suddenly change sex naturally and be able to carry out role of the 
other (females with breastfeeding/gestation for example), then this video 
is clearly not supporting homosexuality in any way. If you want to be gay, 
you're free to do that, just don't drag science along. And to be fair, same 
goes towards people who are arguing against homosexuality using their own 
pseudoscience.﻿
comments.author: Farisss92

comments.text:
I don't know to be honest i do think in humans that the inheritability of 
homosexuality is something that is dictated by nature predominantly like 
prenatal exposure to hormones, but i personally believe that this is 
accentuated by nurture and environmental exposure.

I believe homosexuals are for the most part born that way and i don't 
really see a problem with it i just kind of see it as variation in the gene 
pool. 

As opposed to people like transexuals who at often times take hormones and 
go through sex-reassignment surgery and other horribly painful procedures 
to fit their desired sex. In essence this seems like the same thing but it 
starts becoming a mental illness when people cut of their limbs to become 
something that they are not.

I'm currently taking a Sociology course because i'm interested in the 
psychological aspect of peeps but i really hate a lot of the social science 
concepts like social constructions because they tend to lampshade anything 
scientifically based and go off on their own tangent on topics like gender 
roles and come to conclusions instantly(which just makes them seem like 
pretentious douches) without providing any substantial evidence for their 
claims. I really hate it how gender studies try to "blur" the line between 
gender and sex as well.
comments.author: Schrodingers Kitty

comments.text:
+Schrodingers Kitty, pretty sure that the current prevalent theory about 
homosexuality is that it is more nurture rather than nature. The whole 
thing is still unclear though as we have only few scientific research in 
the area of human sexuality. There was a proposal of gay genes back in the 
90s but there hasn't been any research about it since then. We have started 
to accept that it might have been influenced by environment, mainly 
pre-natal.

I think what BB Summer meant was that gender expression is a social 
construct, sex (as in the gender you're born in) is biological. It's all 
just semantics.

Why hate social science? :d I love them! Politics and Economics mostly lol.
comments.author: Farisss92

comments.text:
+Farisss92 imo this video doesn't support nor dissociate from the 
biological evidence of homosexuals, it simply shows a wide vary of animals 
reproductive systems which determine the sex of the offspring. 

Sexual orientation is a whole different question though, it can stem from 
preference to the nature of a persons genetic makeup. 


I'm pretty skeptical about sexuality as a biological imperative though and 
disagree with +BB Summer Gender is not a social construct it is the result 
of the homo genus being a sexually dimorphic species.
I really hate subjects like social science which lack intellectual rigor.
comments.author: Schrodingers Kitty

comments.author: 葉子

comments.text:
+葉子 Diploids have 2 chromatids (both make up a chromossome, and 2 
chromatids have the same genetic information, slightly altered, since 1 
chromatid came from the mom, and the other one from the dad); while 
haploids only have one chromatid (which is also considered a chromossome in 
this form). 

So, no. The male ants don't pass only one strand of DNA. That wouldn't make 
reproduction possible. I don't know much about this, but I'll deduce that 
the male ant passes his whole genome to the offspring; unlike the queen who 
only passes half of her genome.


Then there's also triploids and tetraploids, and even hexaploids.

comments.author: Kasai Dragoness

comments.text:
+Natsu Dragneel That's wrong. As +TheBlendinman pointed out, a sperm cell 
can carry either and X or Y chromosome, while an ovum can only carry an X 
Chromosome because females are XX under normal conditions. The 50/50 chance 
of becoming a Male or Female comes from the X or Y bearing sperm reaching 
the egg. As I said in my previous comment, where I cited a population 
census that said that there ARE more Men than Women in the world, the Y 
chromosome is much smaller than the X chromosome, so some Scientists 
Hypothesize that the slightly higher number of males in the world is due to 
the Y Bearing Sperm being slightly faster do to the smaller Sex Chromosome.
comments.author: Connor Quinn

comments.text:
+Natsu Dragneel
You seem to misunderstand. A sperm cell can carry either X or Y 
chromosomes. An ovum carries only X. The X from a female can't interact 
with another female X, that would faze out the need for the male gender. If 
we put the prefixes 'm' and 'f' for male and female, this can be easily 
explained.

mX + fX = Female
mY + fX = Male
fX + fX = Impossible with the XY system.

The X chromosome always has to be included in the equation but only one 
'fX' can be used.

comments.text:
I understand all of it except for the last part. The "lizard" box on the 
tree but was told to consider woodtail lizards. is that the same for all 
lizards? The lizards at my house have sex. So if they are both the same sex 
how in the hell do they multiply? All the other boxes were consistent for 
that category but when it got to lizards I had to consider one species.﻿
comments.author: dub yaw

comments.text:
No, not all lizards. The narrator was talking about a specific type of 
lizard called Cnemidophorus or better known as Whiptail Lizard. It is 
called parthenogenesis, the process of reproducing without a mate or any 
gender; asexual reproduction. Plants can do it, clams, oysters, etc.
comments.author: Will Barwa

comments.text:
Actually, not all other boxes were consistent. The boxes did not represent 
entire categories, but single examples from those categories. In some cases 
they could be applied to all species within those categories, but not 
always. Insects for example, include a wide range of species, but what he 
described only talked about social insects. Fish only accounted for 
Clownfish, not all fish undergo a sex change during growth like they do. 
And so, similarly, not all lizards are female only. The one he showcased 
reproduces asexually. Yours don't sound like they do.

comments.text:
When the news of arrival of the Prophet (SalAllahu alaihi wasallam) at 
Al-Madinah reached Abdullah bin Salam, he went to him (i.e. the Prophet 
(SalAllahu alaihi wasallam to ask him about certain things. He said, "I am 
going to ask you about three things which only a Prophet can answer:
What is the sign of the Hour?
What is the first food which the people of Paradise will eat?
Why does a child attract the similarity to his father or to his mother?"
The prophet (SalAllahu alaihi wasallam) replied, "Jibrail has just informed 
me about that."
Ibn Salam said, “He (Jibrail)is the enemy of Jews from amongst the angels."
The Prophet (SalAllahu alaihi wasallam) said,
“As for the first sign of the Hour, it will be a fire that will collect (or 
gather) the people from the east to the west.
As for the first mean which the people of Paradise will eat, it will be the 
caudate (extra) lobe of the fish-liver.
As for the child, if man's discharge precedes the woman's discharge, the 
child attracts the similarity to the man, and if the woman's discharge 
precedes the man's, then the child attracts the similarity to the woman."
On this, Abdullah bin Salam said, "I testify that La ilaha illallah (none 
has the right to be worshipped but Allah)) and that you are the Messenger 
of Allah", and added, "O Allah's Messenger! Jews make such lies as make one 
astonished, so please ask them about me before they know about my 
conversion to Islam."
The Jews cam and the Prophet (SalAllahu alaihi wasallam) said, "What kind 
of man is Abdullah bin Salam among you?" They replied, “The best of us and 
the son of best of us and the most superior among us, and the son of most 
superior among us." the prophet (SalAllahu alaihi wasallam) said, "What 
would you think if Abdullah bin Salam should embrace Islam?" They said, 
"May Allah protect him from that."
The Prophet (SalAllahu alaihi wasallam) repeated his question and they gave 
same answer, then Abdullah came out to them and said, "I testify that La 
ilaha illallah, and that Muhammad (SalAllahu alaihi wasallam) is the 
Messenger of Allah!" On this, the Jews said,"He is the most wicked among us 
and the son of most wicked among us." So they degraded him. On this, he 
(Abdullah bin Salam) said, "It is this that I was afraid of, O Allah's 
Messenger."
 
Sahih Al-Bukhari 5/3938﻿

comments.text:
Yes, this is a great video, but they forgot to mention that gastropods 
(snails and slugs) are hermaphroditic. This means that they have both male 
and female body parts, and can both fertilize and be fertilized. In fact, 
the male organ is like a spear, and mating involves fighting to see which 
one can fertilize the other one first. Come to think of it, that's probably 
why they didn't mention snails and slugs! :D

comments.author: IJustShot MarvinIntheFace

comments.text:
Wait, but if the most dominant male clownfish becomes the most dominant 
female, then the next most dominant male takes the place of the previous 
male, and furthermore those are the only two mating, how do the less 
dominant females ever move up in rank in order to mate... or do they not? 
The only circumstance I can see here is if they fight to become the most 
dominant female but don't kill the current one, thus giving way to the male 
to take her place. So... do all the females just fight 24/7?
